original_title: IASL hosts 16th NAFLIA Conference, driving growth
original_body_lines: The Insurance Association of Sri Lanka (IASL), through its Marketing and Sales Forum, hosted the 16th consecutive NAFLIA Conference at the Monarch Imperial. This landmark event continues to play a critical role in developing and recognising the professionalism of life insurance advisors in the country, reaffirming IASL’s ongoing commitment to elevating industry standards and upholding excellence within the life insurance sector.

This year’s conference was held under the theme “Drivers of Change: Driving Growth in a New World of Insurance.” The event focused on the evolving role of life insurance advisors in a rapidly transforming industry landscape strengthened by technological advancement, shifting customer expectations, demographic changes, regulatory reforms and dynamic market trends. It was emphasized that agents must move beyond adaptation to lead transformative change, proactively embracing innovation, upskilling digitally and delivering customer-centric solutions to build trust and long-term impact.

Over 700 attendees participated in the event, including representatives from the Insurance Regulatory Commission of Sri Lanka (IRCSL), members of IASL, CEOs of leading insurance companies, advisors, team members and other key stakeholders in the industry. The conference created a valuable platform for sharing insights, exploring challenges and collectively shaping the future of life insurance in Sri Lanka.

Among the highlights of the event was the keynote speech delivered by Director of the Postgraduate Institute of Management (PIM) and Chairman, Dr. Asanga Ranasinghe, who shared thought-provoking perspectives on the opportunities presented in the sector with dynamic demographic and technological changes, demanding leadership, growth and transformation in the space.

The conference also featured addresses by the Director General of IRCSL, Damayanthi Fernando, who stated, “Life insurance advisors are vital partners in building financial resilience and trust. Platforms like NAFLIA play a key role in recognizing excellence, encouraging continuous learning and preparing professionals to thrive in a rapidly changing environment. We commend the IASL and the MSF for organising this year’s event under a pertinent theme and look forward for more collaborations to reduce the protection gap in Sri Lanka.”

Also speaking at the event, the President of IASL, Lasitha Wimalaratne, emphasized the importance of resilience, innovation and continuous professional development in navigating the future of the industry.
